Description: Small amulet carved in lapis lazuli, in the shape of a cat-headed cobra (uraeus), probably associated to Bastet; on a small base; fine chevron incisions on front of body of cobra; small suspension loop behind back; burnt and cracked; restored.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Cat-headed cobra amulets appear with the 26th dynasty, with the exception of one from the burial of Tutankhamun, and are seemingly associated to Bastet: Andrews 1994, 35, fig. 41c (good parallel in lapis-lazuli, dated to the Late Period). See also a lapis lazuli amulet in the form of a lion-headed uraeus from Tell Dafana: British Museum EA20666. Andrews, C.A.R. 1994, Amulets of Ancient Egypt, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.257) (phase 3)
Condition: Relativly poor, burnt and cracked, very fragile
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
